Addendum to the Proceedings OOPSLA I Washington, DC-26September-7 October, 7993 Panel Session Status 
of Object-Oriented COBOL Reported by: Joel Van Stee (Moderator) IBM Corporation Members of the panel: 
Megan Adams, Hewlett-Packard Company Dmitry Lenkov, Hewlett-Packard Company Raymond Obin, Micro Focus 
Henry Saade, IBM Corporation The goal of the panel was to inform the audience of the history of the effort 
to define the object-oriented extensions to COBOL, provide a current status, and answer any questions 
from the audience. Just over 100 people attended this panel discussion. Joel Van Stee started the discussion 
with an introduction of the panel members and a brief history of the task group generating the extensions. 
The original sponsor of the group was CODASYL, the ANSI COBOL committee s design group. When CODASYL 
was absorbed by the ANSI COBOL committee, X3J4, the object-oriented committee was separately organized 
as a subcommittee of X3J4, and is now known as X3J4.1. It exists only as long as the parent ANSI COBOL 
committee considers this independent effort required. The aim of the two groups is to have a single COBOL 
standard targeted for publication in 1997. Dmitry Lenkov followed with a discussion of the early history 
and direction of the committee. Dmitry provided valuable information for positioning where the effort 
is today pointing out the continued popularity of COBOL for commercial applications, with both a large 
base of programs and programmers. This discussion recognized that the O-O COBOL committee drew upon the 
experience of existing languages and existing user and implementer approved techniques. The initial design 
decisions included assuring that the large base of code would not be invalidated by the object-oriented 
extensions. The bulk of the discussion by the panel was given by Raymond Obin. The object-oriented COBOL 
committee considers O-O COBOL to be the logical conclusion for object orientation. When commercial programming 
is done using the O-O paradigm (i.e. O-O COBOL is in general use> object orientation will come of age. 
The strategy of O-O COBOL was to combine what is good in COBOL with what is good in object orientation. 
Object orientation will not change the readability and maintainability of COBOL programs nor while it 
change the fact that lots of COBOL programs and COBOL programmers exist in the world. Programs written 
with the new extensions will still resemble COBOL. Object orientation will add those elements to COBOL 
to make it the O-O language of choice for commercial programmers: objects, classes, methods, multiple 
inheritance, persistence, polymorphism, early and late binding, garbage collection, interfaces, and user-defined 
exceptions. Addendum to the Proceedings OOPSLA 93
title: Status of object-oriented COBOL (panel)
